snippet.textDisplay:
NOTE: some misinformed people are recommending i call the video “people with autism” to be more respectful but i reached out to the autistic community and “autistic people” is heavily preferred. please listen to the community before spreading potentially incorrect* information.
ORIGINAL POST: come back next week for I spent a day with 911 EMERGENCY DISPATCHERS -- thank you so much for supporting me and this series :)
luv, anthony padildo
ps: shoutout to everyone who has turned on notifications 🔔 and directly support me in continuing this series.
snippet.textOriginal:
NOTE: some misinformed people are recommending i call the video “people with autism” to be more respectful but i reached out to the autistic community and “autistic people” is heavily preferred. please listen to the community before spreading potentially incorrect* information.
ORIGINAL POST: come back next week for *I spent a day with 911 EMERGENCY DISPATCHERS* -- thank you so much for supporting me and this series :)
luv, anthony padildo
ps: shoutout to everyone who has turned on notifications 🔔 and directly support me in continuing this series.

snippet.textDisplay: As a sibling who's brother has Autism I love this video! However, as you mentioned, the world of Autism is vast to say the least! My brother is in the lower spectrum moderate to severe where he wouldnt be able to keep up having long conversations and just say one phrases. On that note, would you consider doing "Siblings of Autism" as a way to give voice to our loved ones who are in the severe spectrum, as it is vastly different from those on the high spectrum :)
snippet.textOriginal: As a sibling who's brother has Autism I love this video! However, as you mentioned, the world of Autism is vast to say the least! My brother is in the lower spectrum moderate to severe where he wouldnt be able to keep up having long conversations and just say one phrases. On that note, would you consider doing "Siblings of Autism" as a way to give voice to our loved ones who are in the severe spectrum, as it is vastly different from those on the high spectrum :)

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Anthony. I have aspergers syndrome and to be honest i feel its a gift and a curse. You see things in a different light and also see things in the same light as other people. I think we are pushed aside a lot and feel like we arent accepted as we should. Like you dont belong if speaking your mind. I feel people have routines and my advice to truely break free they need to destroy the routine barriers and ask questions on what the world is teaching us. I have a degree in software but in terms of jobs, i feel that because i have aspergers syndrome, you aint good enough. In school was a trying time because teachers assume that you are like the rest who can keep up in pace and have the same understanding when in reality we dont. In my life i come to realise its all of about the methods of understanding and when we understand we shine better than most. In a typical relationships with women/men its also a challenge because they dont get you. And if you say to them i have autism i feel they automatically think ok if i start a relationship with this person i might have to be a carer. So i think we are at a disadvantage.
snippet.textOriginal: Hi Anthony. I have aspergers syndrome and to be honest i feel its a gift and a curse. You see things in a different light and also see things in the same light as other people. I feel people have routines and my advice to truely break free they need to destroy the routine barriers and ask questions on what the world is teaching us. I have a degree in software but in terms of jobs, i feel that because i have aspergers syndrome, you aint good enough. In school was a trying time because teachers assume that you are like the rest who can keep up in pace and have the same understanding when in reality we dont. In my life i come to realise its all of about the methods of understanding and when we understand we shine better than most. In a typical relationships with women/men its also a challenge because they dont get you. And if you say to them i have autism i feel they automatically think ok if i start a relationship with this person i might have to be a carer. So i think we are at a disadvantage.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone with autism that affected my life before I even knew I was autistic, I’m so glad to see this video exists. There’s a lot of videos on youtube that feed false information about this. Sometimes I wished I didn’t have my disorder so I could see the world like most, but most of the time recently I’ve accepted it as a part of my life. And I’m proud to have because it gives me a chance to inform those who don’t know much about autism.

Also I’m even more glad for this video existing because a close friend of mine recently found out she might be on spectrum. Their parents never told them until her mom did accidentally and recently, and it wasn’t put on her personal record because of that.
snippet.textOriginal:
As someone with autism that affected my life before I even knew I was autistic, I’m so glad to see this video exists. There’s a lot of videos on youtube that feed false information about this. Sometimes I wished I didn’t have my disorder so I could see the world like most, but most of the time recently I’ve accepted it as a part of my life. And I’m proud to have because it gives me a chance to inform those who don’t know much about autism.

Also I’m even more glad for this video existing because a close friend of mine recently found out she might be on spectrum. Their parents never told them until her mom did accidentally and recently, and it wasn’t put on her personal record because of that.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who is on the spectrum, it’s sweet that you’re trying to learn and teach more to people, but j don’t think I would know how to answer if someone asked me if I wanted a cure, I’ve only ever known being autistic and I have no clue what it’s like. The only thing that could tip the scale is that it’s the hardest things ever to focus when you’re young
But this video is still awesome and I love the way you talk to everyone, very sweet!

snippet.textDisplay:
I kinda hate the term autistic
Because I got kicked out off school because of
Teachers thought every kid with autism was the same
So they said I couldn't have friends or talk to anyone because they thought I would do anything for attention
And when I tried to say how much bullshit it was and that that wasn't even my form of autism
They would laugh at me
Plus people used it as a cruse word at me at home

snippet.textDisplay: As someone diagnosed with Aspergers I wanted to say thank you so much for this video as it really demonstrated how people on the spectrum are valuable, wonderful and interesting people x
snippet.textOriginal: As someone diagnosed with Aspergers I wanted to say thank you so much for this video as it really demonstrated how people on the spectrum are valuable, wonderful and interesting people x

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for spreading awareness! I often notice that people think autism means that you can't function and that is so not true for a lot of us. I am a high functioning autistic woman and I have a bachelors degree in social work and I help kids and families with autism every day!
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you for spreading awareness! I often notice that people think autism means that you can't function and that is so not true for a lot of us. I am a high functioning autistic woman and I have a bachelors degree in social work and I help kids and families with autism every day!

snippet.textDisplay: I have high functioning autism. I used to struggle a lot, got bullied for being different. Did not understand the world. But I spend my whole childhood learning how to be 'normal'. Now I have a bachelors degree in social work. I work with autistic kids and families every day and help them like I needed help when I was younger. And no one even sees now that I have a disorder. Only I can tell because it is in my head and body. But it doesn't show anymore.
snippet.textOriginal: I have high functioning autism. I used to struggle a lot, got bullied for being different. Did not understand the world. But I spend my whole childhood learning how to be 'normal'. Now I have a bachelors degree in social work. I work with autistic kids and families every day and help them like I needed help when I was younger. And no one even sees now that I have a disorder. Only I can tell because it is in my head and body. But it doesn't show anymore.

snippet.textDisplay: First off, it's crazy to see how many people get offended over something not even pertaining to them. Stop assuming that people will get as easily offended as you. Second, and this is a big one, what matters more is the person's intentions. Too many people go crazy right away without giving the person a chance to correct/clarify themselves or apologize. Clearly, Anthony had no intention in offending anyone in this video.
snippet.textOriginal: First off, it's crazy to see how many people get offended over something not even pertaining to them. Stop assuming that people will get as easily offended as you. Second, and this is a big one, what matters more is the person's intentions. Too many people go crazy right away without giving the person a chance to correct/clarify themselves or apologize. Clearly, Anthony had no intention in offending anyone in this video.

snippet.textDisplay: Before I always felt different and weird, and thought of things and connections that no one would understand or imagine, like how Stranger Things relates to Star Wars, or how the seasons relate to one other on opposite times of the year, being able to name the day when the sunlight is the same intensity as it’s opposing season, thinking in numbers and balancing things with your mind, believing telekinesis & telepathy are real, and the ability to shut everything else out to master anything that interests you with perfect clarity. I was diagnosed last year after my aunt said I have it, and everything in my life fell into place and made sense at last. Autistic people are in a way specially gifted with abilities in one area or another. I learned about autism through Temple Grandin & saw it in characters I relate to like Eleven, Mike Wheeler & Will Byers in Stranger Things, Gray Mitchell in Jurassic World, and Kylo Ren/Ben Solo in Star Wars.

I was diagnosed last year after my aunt said I have it, and everything in my life fell into place and made sense at last. snippet.textDisplay: I have Asperger's Syndrome, but my mum only told me last year and she's known since I was a child. We were watching a documentary on it so that's why it came up and there was on girl they looking at, where Mum said she reminded her of me. She retracted it and said that they thought I had it, when I told my dad by saying "don't let it define you" but I'm like, it's literally the only thing in my life that makes sense.
snippet.textOriginal: I have Asperger's Syndrome, but my mum only told me last year and she's known since I was a child. We were watching a documentary on it so that's why it came up and there was on girl they looking at, where Mum said she reminded her of me. She retracted it and said that they thought I had it, when I told my dad by saying "don't let it define you" but I'm like, it's literally the only thing in my life that makes sense.

snippet.textDisplay: Just a personal note: As a child I had twice the amount of immunizations as was normal due to immigration issues. The second round of vaccines was given mostly within a two week span (including several at a time). Vaccines do not cause Autism.
snippet.textOriginal: Just a personal note: As a child I had twice the amount of immunizations as was normal due to immigration issues. The second round of vaccines was given mostly within a two week span (including several at a time). Vaccines do not cause Autism.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sometimes the kindest thing you can do for someone with ASD is laugh with us. We don't need kid gloves

I like how Anthony associated his panic attacks without pretending they're the same

Aspies tend to be good drivers because we like to follow the rules
snippet.textOriginal:
Sometimes the kindest thing you can do for someone with ASD is laugh with us. We don't need kid gloves

snippet.textDisplay:
Growing up, Asperger's was a curse. now, it's a blessing and a curse. Services need to be widely available, but a cure isn't realistic. Still, it's exhausting.

I had every possible service growing up. People are usually surprised when they learn about my ASD, but it's still exhausting and it has cost me a lot over the years.

I can't stand "person first" language

Teachers can be big bullies
snippet.textOriginal:
Growing up, Asperger's was a curse. now, it's a blessing and a curse. Services need to be widely available, but a cure isn't realistic. Still, it's exhausting. 

I had every possible service growing up. People are usually surprised when they learn about my ASD, but it's still exhausting and it has cost me a lot over the years.

I can't stand  "person first" language

Teachers can be big bullies

snippet.textDisplay: I am born autistic and  I had my mom to wait 6 years till i could even take medicine from doctors and i can tell you my  childhood was unique, I used to always be the smart kid, and also the super sensitive kid up till the 7th Grade, I was nervous but I was able to get a lot of friends, now I'm older and since I discovered the real world I'm not that smart anymore and making friends is just a nightmare so maybe I got tantrums when somebody messed with me but I was happy most of the time, this feeling sadly faded away  in 7th Grade as school gets more strict
snippet.textOriginal: I am born autistic and  I had my mom to wait 6 years till i could even take medicine from doctors and i can tell you my  childhood was unique, I used to always be the smart kid, and also the super sensitive kid up till the 7th Grade, I was nervous but I was able to get a lot of friends, now I'm older and since I discovered the real world I'm not that smart anymore and making friends is just a nightmare so maybe I got tantrums when somebody messed with me but I was happy most of the time, this feeling sadly faded away  in 7th Grade as school gets more strict

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you so much for this video Anthony i see so many people treat people with autism like they're children especially autistic adults so i really appreciate how respectful and professional this video is. I am not autistic but my older brother is a moderate to high functioning autistic adult (18yrs) and i am currently trying to help him learn that he deserves respect from people and to not let my family walk all over him, him and i work on his speech as well and as the years have gone by hes much more understandable now and i am very proud of him, ill show him this video and explain to him what respect really is and just how much he needs to know that he deserves it just as much as any other person
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you so much for this video Anthony i see so many people treat people with autism like they're children especially autistic adults so i really appreciate how respectful and professional this video is. I am not autistic but my older brother is a moderate to high functioning autistic adult (18yrs) and i am currently trying to help him learn that he deserves respect from people and to not let my family walk all over him, him and i work on his speech as well and as the years have gone by hes much more understandable now and i am very proud of him, ill show him this video and explain to him what respect really is and just how much he needs to know that he deserves it just as much as any other person

snippet.textDisplay: I remember when I was diagnosed with ASD,  I was diagnosed last year, when I was 13. I'm 14, though. My dad doesn't believe in certified psychologists so he makes my mom not care either. So since I can't look people in the eye, stand loud noises, or even let people tough me, my parents get mad when I protest their yelling and screaming.
snippet.textOriginal: I remember when I was diagnosed with ASD,  I was diagnosed last year, when I was 13. I'm 14, though. My dad doesn't believe in certified psychologists so he makes my mom not care either. So since I can't look people in the eye, stand loud noises, or even let people tough me, my parents get mad when I protest their yelling and screaming.

snippet.textDisplay: I think this is a great video with good intentions, however I think it should be called "I spent a day with high functioning autistic people." There are many low functioning autistic people who are nothing like this and it can erase them from a conversation if this difference isn't noted.
snippet.textOriginal: I think this is a great video with good intentions, however I think it should be called "I spent a day with high functioning autistic people." There are many low functioning autistic people who are nothing like this and it can erase them from a conversation if this difference isn't noted.

snippet.textDisplay:
From a student studying Social Work: First person language is highly encouraged with most populations but individuals with disabilities prefer either/prefer their disabilities to be acknowledged first because it’s a part of who they are! It’s become their identity, they are proud of it!

I’m all for being politically correct but make sure you know before trying to correct other people! You are all so great for even thinking about it though! ❤️
snippet.textOriginal:
From a student studying Social Work: First person language is highly encouraged with most populations but individuals with disabilities prefer either/prefer their disabilities to be acknowledged first because it’s a part of who they are! It’s become their identity, they are proud of it!

snippet.textDisplay:
Forgive my bad English, but as the older brother of two kids with autism I used to think it was a huge burden or weight to carry especially for my mother, but as I grew up basically raising them and it became part of my life, I met other people, those of dealt or went through similar issues and its honestly an experience that helps you understand different perspectives, like how some single mothers and/or hard-working families have to go through on a daily basis, it opened my mind to do my best to help them if I ever see someone struggling with a child who has autism, all this truly changes you, and in the end, they are human beings.


If you ever see a person struggling with a child that has autism, don't find ways to dismiss them, help them by at least asking if they need something, make them feel welcomed, not just the child, but the mother or father that usually feel left out by entire communities over something they have very little control of.
snippet.textOriginal:
Forgive my bad English, but as the older brother of two kids with autism I used to think it was a huge burden or weight to carry especially for my mother, but as I grew up basically raising them and it became part of my life, I  met other people, those of dealt or went through similar issues and its honestly an experience that helps you understand different perspectives, like how some single mothers and/or hard-working families have to go through on a daily basis, it opened my mind to do my best to help them if I ever see someone struggling with a child who has autism, all this truly changes you, and in the end, they are human beings.


If you ever see a person struggling with a child that has autism, don't find ways to dismiss them, help them by at least asking if they need something, make them feel welcomed, not just the child, but the mother or father that usually feel left out by entire communities over something they have very little control of.

snippet.textDisplay: Great video Anthony, if you found the topic interesting. I could clarify on many of the points these 3 beautiful interviewees you had come in. I struggle on the spectrum of life with bipolar and ADHD disorders, it's been a hard task to understand it all but I've done so this start of the year. Plan on writing a book, 3 albums or ballads, 2 movies and then to finish off, a video game. I need help and I like to help, and you like to help people and might not realize it but need help also. We all do, I can send you my email if you'd like to get in contact and discuss the worlds future more. Thanks for reading this, much love and all the best with your future endeavors.
snippet.textOriginal: Great video Anthony, if you found the topic interesting. I could clarify on many of the points these 3 beautiful interviewees you had come in. I struggle on the spectrum of life with bipolar and ADHD disorders, it's been a hard task to understand it all but I've done so this start of the year. Plan on writing a book, 3 albums or ballads, 2 movies and then to finish off, a video game. I need help and I like to help, and you like to help people and might not realize it but need help also. We all do, I can send you my email if you'd like to get in contact and discuss the worlds future more. Thanks for reading this, much love and all the best with your future endeavors.

I got bullied as a kid and wondered what was wrong with me, but I don't have autism or anything "wrong" per se, kids can just be really mean.  Hopefully this video educates others, good job, Anthony

snippet.textDisplay: I have high functioning autism and woumd like to connect with some more people on the spectrum to exchange daily experiences and struggles. Looking forward to someone hitting me up or asking me a question about my experience.
snippet.textOriginal: I have high functioning autism and woumd like to connect with some more people on the spectrum to exchange daily experiences and struggles. Looking forward to someone hitting me up or asking me a question about my experience.

snippet.textDisplay:
I grew up in Germany and while in elementary school we had an autistic kid in our class. He had his own personal supervisor, and since the adults explained to us that he was a little different; showed affection in a different way and that when he did that or this he meant it in a different way, we never even thought that he was out of the norm! He was just Marius, a little special, but still fun to play with.
That really helped me in my adult life and I've never understood people who see autism as this weird abstract thing. I wish more people could have this experience in school, the ones with autism and the ones without.
snippet.textOriginal:

He was just Marius, a little special, but still fun to play with.
That really helped me in my adult life and I've never understood people who see autism as this weird abstract thing. I wish more people could have this experience in school, the ones with autism and the ones without.
